On Friday, Governor Roy Cooper extended the school closure order that began on March 14 through the end of this school year. Although schools are closed to in-person instruction, Moore County Schools will continue remote learning for the rest of this school year.

In anticipation of students returning to school in the fall, and new measures the Governor has indicated will be in place to protect the health of students and staff, a district re-entry team has been assembled consisting of central office administrators and principals. The re-entry team will be planning a path moving forward once schools are permitted to resume in-person instruction. The team is also anticipating guidance from the state for proceeding with summer programs and day care and making plans to respond accordingly. Those plans will be contingent on guidelines as recommended by state and federal officials. Further information will be forthcoming as it is developed.

The Moore County Board of Education, Moore County Board of Commissioners, Mayor and Council Members from the Town of Aberdeen, and Principals and Assistant Principals from Aberdeen Elementary and Primary Schools, were given a sneak peak at the new Aberdeen Elementary School, located at 525 Farrell Parkway off Rt. 5 at Pit Link Lane.

The new school will consolidate Aberdeen Elementary and Aberdeen Primary Schools into one K-5 school with a capacity for 800 students. It is designed to provide opportunities for self-guided learning and team-teaching strategies. The design utilizes a "main street" and compact "finger plan" organization to adapt to the shape of the site. The energy efficient design will feature modern technologies including geothermal heat and air conditioning systems, and a wireless technology environment to promote student success and reduce absenteeism.

The new Aberdeen Elementary School will open in fall of 2020.

post_text: Demolition of the old Pinehurst Elementary began today, the third and final school slated to be built as part of a $103 million bond referendum supported by 80% of voters in May 2018. The new school will replace an aging, existing school on the same site, and will have capacity for 800 students. The new Pinehurst Elementary School will open in August 2021.

This week is School Psychology Awareness Week. This year's theme is "Find Your Focus," which can have a variety of meanings such as paying attention, being able to see an idea more clearly, identifying an area of interest, or being persistent and determined in one's effort. Focusing can help us set goals, identify action steps, communicate needs, and engage in discussions that help create the connections necessary for students to develop critical academic and social emotional skills. (Nation Association of School Psychologists)

Moore County Schools is fortunate to have an amazing Student Support Services Team to guide our students and help them Find Their Focus!

post_text: Walls are going up at the new Southern Pines Elementary School in Morganton Park North. The new K-5 elementary school will replace Southern Pines Primary School (grades K-2) and Southern Pines Elementary School (grades 3-5) buildings, consolidating two schools into one. The school will be a two-story structure with a capacity for 800 students. The school will welcome students starting January 2021.

post_text: On Friday afternoon, we broke ground on the new auxiliary gym and classrooms at North Moore High School. The 38,963 sq.ft. addition will house an auxiliary gym, wrestling room, six classrooms, four science labs and classroom space for special needs students. The locker rooms are also being renovated and updated to today's standards. Above all, in an effort to enhance security, an enclosed corridor will connect the current and new auxiliary gymnasiums to the front administration building and there will be improved accessibility to accommodate all individuals.

Today, the 2018-2019 nominees for the Eileen Vansant Volunteer of the Year Award gathered for an appreciation luncheon at Weymouth Center for the Arts and Humanities. The Eileen Vansant Volunteer of the Year award is given each year to an individual who has dedicated time and service to our schools.

Congratulations Wayne Osborne 2018-2019 Volunteer of the Year! Mr. Osborne has been a volunteer at Union Pines High School for 30 years. He has built 30 musical sets and countless non-musical show sets. He has coached the Marching Vikings and the North Moore drumlines for several years. He also offers free percussion workshops to middle school bands. Thank you, Mr. Osborne, for your support and dedication to the Moore County Schools community.

Thank you to all the other nominees and volunteers for selflessly donating your time and talents to our schools!
